Leonardo Quaglia e il Rev. Giuseppe Valdambrini, primo parroco di New Havèn e l'al tro di Waterbury, sono stati insigniti della Croce di Cavaliere della Corona d'Italia. Conosciamo il patriottismo dei due dotti pre lati del Connecticut e siamo convinti che la onore f icenza reale non poteva essere più degna. Quaglia e Valdambrini due intelletti pre clari delle nostre comunità sono ben noti alle nostre masse, in mezzo alla quali, specie durante il periodo della grande guerra, esplicarono un'at tività formidabile a favore della Patria e della Croce Rossa. CITTADINI ITALO-AMERICANI. Parole non nostre, che allargano i polmoni. Leggete: "Fra i rappresentanti di quarantotto nazioni (contando come una tutte le divisioni dell'impero britannico) naturalizzati il mese scorso, gli Italia ni che idoneamente domandavano la cittadinanza americana di nuovo si sono messi alla testa di tutti gli altri, costituendo quasi il venti per cento del totale. "V'è qualche cosa di bello in questo rapido adattamento delle persone di nascita italiana alle condizioni del crogiuolo dell'amalgama. Essi af ferrano subito i principii del nostro Governo e riconoscono più presto di tutti gli altri stranieri i vantaggi della partecipazione personale alla scel ta degli agenti elettivi. E nella loro ansia di assi milazione vie la prova evidente dell'intenzione di divenire abitanti permanenti del paese, in cui vi vono. "Si può dire con certezza che dei 2,473 italiani naturalizzati il mese scorso, una gran parte eser citerà regolarmente il privilegio del voto, più dei cittadini di nascita. Ciò che è difficile ad ottenere, per regola è maggiormente apprezzato. "Gli americani, in gran numero, sono proni alla negligenza nell'uso del loro diritto di nascita, fatto a cui è dovuto molto mal governo. Molti americani di nascita che non figurano nelle liste di registrazione, possono trarre profitto rilevando l'importanza che tutti i politicanti stagionati at tribuiscono al cosiddetto "voto straniero". L'ARCO DELL'AMICIZIA. Nella città di Chefoo (Cina) è stato eretto un arco che è stata battezzato "Dell'Amicizia", per cementare i buoni rapporti tra la Cina e gli Stati Uniti. Si domanda: Buoni rapporti con il popolo americano o con il dollaro americano? Il vecchio sapiente Salomone, vissuto mille anni prima dell'era cristiana risponde: Al denaro tutto si spiega ed in nome e per amor del danaro tutto si fa. Ed aggiunge: Anche questa è vanità! In ogni modo l'arco dell'Amicizia serve se non altro a suscitare dei buoni sentimenti, il che conta assai nella tela della civiltà. MARITI E MOGLI. Un'importante causa è stata discussa nei giorni scorsi a Parigi. Un americano, certo Nel son Morris di Chicago, aveva proibito alla moglie, un'attrice francese, di prodursi in una "musica hall", parigina. La moglie, in perfetto accordo col direttore del teatro, si è rifiutata di ubbidire al marito, e questi a sua volta ha citato entrambi per danni morali e materiali. Il manager del Music Hall si è difeso dicendo che poiché i coniugi Mor ris si sono sposati negli Stati Uniti la moglie, in base alle leggi americane, non è obbligata ad ub bidire il marito. Ma la corte francese ha sentenziato che tutti coloro che vivono in Francia debbono rispettare la legge francese secondo cui la moglie deve ubbi dire il marito. Ed ha obbligato il direttore dei Music Hall a pagare un indennizzo di 2000 dol lari al Morris, onde ricompensarlo del "ridicolo" di cui era stato oggetto in seguito alla disobbe dienza della moglie. E' dunque inteso. Fmariti americani, per avere la soddisfazione di essere obbediti dalle mo gli, devono andare in Francia. La Costituzione degli Stati Uniti mantiene che nessuna per sona può essere deprivata della sua libertà senza prima avere avuto tutti i vantaggi conferite gli dalla legge; cioè tale persona deve essere processata in aperta corte dinanzi al Giudice e Giu rati; deve essere predente du rante il processo e deve avere il diritto di difendersi per mezzo di un avvocato il quale dovrà otte nere per l'accusato tutti i diritti che gli appartengono per legge. Se l'accusato non crede di avere icevuto una decisione giusta, igli ha il diritto di domandare ..m'altra causa davanti ad una Corte Superiore. Fino a quan do questa Corte Superiore non abbi reso la sua decisione finale, l'accusato ha il diritto di andare in libertà provvisorio sotto cau zione "bail". Tale cauzione vuol dire che qualch'uno garantisce di pagare una data somma se l'ac cusato non si presenta quando è fatto il processo. Per legge nessuna persona persona negli Stati Uniti può andare in prigione senza esser stato sottomesso ad un processo di fronte a giurati ; se qualunque persona si trova in prigione sen za avere ricevuto una causa, la Costituzione degli Stati Uniti gli da il diritto di cercare di otte nere la sua libertà per mezzo della legge chiamata "Writ of Habeas Corpus". Il "Writ of Habeas Corpus" è il diritto più grande e il più forte salvataggio che appartiene a qualunque uomo o donna negli Stati Uniti ed è necessario che ognuno ne comprenda il vero si gnificato. La legge di "Habeas Corpus" è stata in uso in Inghil terra da più di milla anni e pren de il suo nome dal fatto che a quei tempi in Inghilterra tutti i documenti legali erano scritti in Latino; la vera traduzione della parola "Habeas Corpus" è "Do vete produrre il Corpo del Tal di Tale". Questa rappresenta un ordine di una Corte Superiore al Direttore delle Prigioni, cioè ri chiede di produrre la persona nominata in Corte ad un dato tempo davanti al Giudice che firma la richiesta di "Habeas Corpus". Il "Writ di Habeas Corpus" non è di valore soltanto alle per sone in prigione, perchè vi sono altre maniere che una persona può essere deprivata della sua libertà. Per esempio, delle volte delle persone vengono detenute contro la loro volontà, in ospedali privati o in manicomi per pazzi da parenti che hanno interesse nel farli passare per pazzi o ma lati. Anche se una persona è ve ramente pazza, egli ha il diritto di domandare per mezzo del del "Habeas Corpus" di essere portato in Corte e di far a questa decidere se egli può essere rila sciato in libertà o no. Uno stra niero che viene ordinato depor tato dall'autorità d'immigrazione ha il diritto, in caso che i suoi parenti o amici faccino la do manda per il "Writ di Habeas Corpus" di farsi portare in Corte e di far decidere al Giudice se egli deve essere deportato o no. Molti stranieri hanno potuto scampare una deportazione in giusta in questo modo. Se un minorenne si arruola nell'eserci to o nella marina senza il con senso dei genitori, i genitori possono ottenere la 'sua licenza per mezzo del Habeas Corpus. Se uno dei genitori viene deprivato della custodia di un figlio, egli può domandare di averlo per mezzo di "Habeas Corpus". Generalmente, la domanda per Habeas Corpus deve essere fatta dalla stessa persona detenuta, però, un marito ha il diritto di fare tale formale domanda per la moglie ed una moglie per il ma rito; il rilascio di un minorenne deve essere domandato dai geni tori ; dal guardiano o dal parente più vicino. Generalmente, il Writ di Habeas Corpus non verrà dato ! presso la domanda di un estra ! neo che non ha nessuna paren tela con il prigioniero. In quasi tutti gli Stati le Corti di Appello hanno la giurisdizione sul Writ di Habeas Corpus. La Corte Suprema degli Stati Unit può rilasciare il Writ di Habeas Corpus per qualsiasi parte del la Nazione, mentre le Corti Sta tali e le U. S. District Courts non hanno il diritto di darlo che per i propri distretti. Subscription $2.00 per Year Entered as second class matter, October 21 1914, at Post Office at Bridgeport, Conn, under the Act of March 3, 1879 Single Copy 5 Cts. 5 I TTTTT TOTT TTTTT pom TTTTT a D iritto di Habeas Corpus Vi VVV4 a ff -. fMin"iI I t X I I I I I i I ifr j E iversità? 60 ENGLISH SECTION By AREL PREMIER MUSSOLINI Benito Mussolini, Italy's Premier addressed a crowd of 150,000 workers in Milan, May 25, telling them that discipline of the laboring classes "firmly united around the symbol of the lictor's rods" is the element that is elevating Italy's economic situation above that of other nations. Cannon kept firing salvos in honor of II Duce's visit, throwing varicolored confetti over the crowd's heads. A powerful radio outside the courtyard filled the big park with national and Fascist airs. "It is unnecessary to recount what the Fascist Government has done for labor. We think of your interests, all your needs, because we love you as workers and fellow-Italians," the Premier said. Previously the Premier had attended a gathering in Balilla Stadium before 35,000 youngsters. Before a seething crowd of Fascists the day before, packed into the great square before the famous cathedral, Mussolini spoke with defiance for Fascism's enemies, and made a call for a cele bration here in 1932 of the second decade of the revolution. Some spectators said there were 300,000 gathered to hear lì Duce's speech. The Fascist leader had some difficulty in controlling the excitement of his auditors who broke out into shouts of "Down with France" several times. Mussolini silenced them with a gesture. He said alleged reports of the debarkation of Italian troops in Albania were "absurd". Commemorating Italy's entrance into the war 15 years ago, and recalling her 652,000 fallen, he declared "We do not comme morate this date to revive old hatreds, because we are reconciled fully end loyally with our enemies of yesterday, and even linked hi sincere friendship with some of them". He warned the Blackshirts not to let the people "go to sleep before the baaing of lambs that are really wolves, so that they may not tomorrow wrake up before one of the more or less tragic surprises of history." He hotly denied that Italy's economic situation was bad, and said it was not worse than that of any other country. "Some people would like to see me make a ministry of the eld style, but they forgot that there is no longer a ministry, but r. regime formed, not of parliamentary groups but by the bloody efforts of the Blackshirts. It is a revolution that had a long period of struggle. I am the chief and the creator of this regime and must be its defender. "I make no vague affirmations. We are sufficiently well informed of what is being prepared elsewhere and of the dominant spirit among certain of our neighbors." WHAT DO YOU OWE YOUR CITY? Many individuals labor under the delusion that their city owes them something. The other side of the question is true. They owe ..their- citf--something. One thing that should be pondered by every one is the question of how he may best serve his city. Giles H. Stilwell, in retiring as president of the Chamber of Commerce at Syracuse, N. Y. gave utterance to some statements which we think might be well considered by every individual. His remarks are wholesome. Concerning what one owes his city, Mr. Stilwell said: "My city owes me nothing. If accounts were balanced at this date, I wtsuld be the debtor. Haven't I, all these years, lived within the limits of the city and shared all its benefits? Haven't I had he benefit of its schools, churches and hospitals? Haven't I had ;he use of its library, parks and public places? Haven't I had the protection of its fire, police and health department? Haven't its people during all this time, been gathering for me, from the four corners of the earth, food for my table, clothing for my body and material for my home? Hasn't this city furnished the patronage oy which I have succeeded in my business? Hasn't it furnished he best friends of my life, whose ideals have been my inspiration, whose kind words have been my cheer and whose helpfulness has carried me "over my greatest difficulties? What shall I give in :eturn? Not simply taxes which cover so small a part of what I have received. I want to give more, I want, of my own free vili, to give enough so that I can rightfully say, "This is my City", so that I can take pride in "my city"; so that I can take oride in its prosperity, in the honors which come to its citizens, md in all that makes it greater and better. I can do this only y becoming a part of the city by giving to it generously of myself. In this way only can I, even in small part, pay the great ù-.bt I owe." HELPING BOYS "No man stands so straight as when he stoops to help a boy." It is such an easy matter to become careless and pay no attention to boys. Men are busy with the affairs of business. Worrying details occupy one's thoughts. Yet, all about us, are )oys who need help the help that comes from an encouraging void, a helping hand, a little boost. All these helpful things take nit just a minute of any man's time, and yet they mean so much Lo a boy. It does not take long for a boy to grow and develop into a nan. It may be that what we may do today will have a big influence on what kind of man he will be. Are we doing the thing Lhat will help the boy? Just a cordial word of greeting in the lorning as the boy is on the way to school will" frequently give the lad just the needed encouragement for that particular day. Do we do that? Can we truthfully say that we have been the means and channel by which a boy gets inspiration to do better things. There is so much we can do in boys' work without even having to take any time to do it. Most men are willing: to do this if they only realized how easily it can be done. PUBLICITY FOR CRIME NEWS If crime news in the leading newspapers of large cities in the United States constiutes only 2 per cent of all news, as a sociologist reported after a survey of these papers, it is possible that the :ress does not deal sufficiently with crime. The sociologist sur veyed 103 newspapers, and possibly the reason more crime news -vas not printed was because newspapers were interested in publi shing only the sensational. The power of the press to tell the truth md the whole truth, even to relating all that happens in civil and ;riminal courts, should not be impaired. Newspaper are the best links between the citizens and the ourt room. News is the most effective of teachers and for that -ason it should be prepared and printed with fact and wisdom. . e responsability of the newspaper is stupendous and on it rests V o reputation of a nation and that nation's public opinion, ideals ,id common decency. There has been some criticism of the press as unfair. I do not beil?ve that such criticism is justified. As a whole, newspapers are accurate and speak the truth. They would not exist for long if they did not. Nor do I agree with some that the printing of crime news is an incentive to crime. Rather, I think, it is a deterrent. It makes people think and some good generally comes from their thinking.

In breve: è il pubblico che ENGLISH SECTION ByAREL. THE LAW OF INDEPENDENCE By Dr. Joseph Pantaleone The nature of every living being leads it to look out primarily for its own welfare. The law of egoism dominates the entire animal kingdom and most men are subject to it. Rare indeed is the generous soul who looks out for his neighbor's well-being above his own. And so in a world in which the vast majority of living organism are only interested in themselves, it is only the fool who leaves to others the carrying out of important details pertaining to his own prosperity, comfort, and general well-being. The old wisdom holds: the best way to do a thing is to do it yourself. The satisfaction and joy of knowing that all our achievements and comforts were procured by our own efforts is very inspiring and produces the finest type of character in a man. It makes him stand on his own feet. One must develop one's character by doing things for himself. No one else can eat, breathe, or sleep for you and so if you want wisdom, happiness, or success, there are certain things which you must do yourself and which no one else can possibly do for you. In other words, he who expects to be a man of the world must be a go-getter and must not leave important details for others to do for him. He certainly won't be developing his abilities to their full extent by using this method of shifting the burden, and furthermore, the job will either not be done at all or in most cases, it will be badly done. The trend in modern education today is toward letting the student think and do things for himself. Te development of initiative and the application of the law of indepen dence in thought and action are being more and more recognized by our leading educators. The progress of humanity through the centuries has been a beautiful example of the law of independence. Man has had to fight his own battle all by himself against the grim overpowering forces of Nature. Alone he had to face the infinite against tre mendous odds and he won ! Alone are all beings born and' alone must each face his ultimate dissolution. Life is a solitary adventure each must work out his own salvation and since each one of us presents a different problem, the solution is always different in each case. It is this which makes all true education so difficult. The struggle for existence is keen in the modern world, but it is preeminently a solitary struggle. Each individual openly is fighting the other in the grand scramble for supremacy! Woe to the weak! Woe to those who have things made easy for them! He who recognizes and applies this principle of independence in all his actions and who early learns to do everthing for himself, always seeking the arduous path rather than the easy one will in the end far outrun his competitors and find himself triumphantly acclaimed as a conquering hero by all those who possess the deepest wisdom. CHEATING MOTORISTS mo s'egli sa isarla onde ricavar A vacation trip by automobile, whether it lasts three days òr ';hree weeks is about as fine a recreation as possible. However, there are two or three sizable flies in the ointment, and all of us who hit the open road will find them in full measure. Our roads zo thru charming scenery; but ramshackle hot dog stands, ugly filling stations and blatant bill boards rob the motorist of a good deal of enjoyment that is rightfully his. The worst of it all is ;hat all this ugliness is quite unnecessary, but is there any reason vvhy they have to be ugly? A little landscaping along a new lighway is not so very expensive. And the billboards is there my reason on earth why they should be stuck up right at the nost beautiful spots along the highway ? Arouse public sentiment can do much to get rid of these eyesores. Each individual notorist can help by vowing not to patronize any refreshment or rilling station that is not at least passably presentable in its out ward appearance and by slapping a one-man boycott on any business outfit that insults his sense of beauty with an ugly Ullboard in a spot where he wants to look at the open country. PARTNERS IN PROSPERITY You and Bridgeport are partners. If Bridgeport prospers, you prosper if Bridgeport goes backward you lose. Your interests are here. When you patronize outside merchants jhain stores or stores owned by outsiders, the money you spend can never be used towards the growth of this community. When you spend your money with Bridgeport merchants you iivest it in Bridgeport and the investment will pay dividends in aaking Bridgeport a better place in which to live. Bridgeport merchants make it possible for you to live in and enjoy the many advantages in Bridgeport. Their taxes maintain our streets, schools and other public institutions. Before spending your money with the chain stores give the Bridgeport merchant a chance, but make him give you the sanif price, quality and service offered you elsewhere. You are entitled to this, and he is entitled to your business, provided he meets these requirements. CURB-CRUISERS AGAIN TO BE SEEN ON OUR STREETS We have again the curb-cruiser with us. It is becoming a not uncommon sight to see a car being slowly driven along, the occupants urging girls on the sidewalk to go for a ride. A girl is silly who goes for a drive with unknown men and is seeking trouble of the wost kind. Girls, pestered in such a way, should make a note of the number ef the car and turn it over to police authorities. Lets put a stop to this form of meanness. MEANING WELL AND DOING WELL Some Bridgeport people mean well, but never do well. They are always intending to do something that never gets done. Instead f taking a just pride in accomplishment, they are continually humiliated by the inadequacy of their excuses. They do not even drift with the tide of humanity, but are simply switched into the eddies of life. For them there is a beginning, and an end, but nothing in between. They have neither true friends nor bitter enemies because they do nothing to inspire either friendship or enmity. They are nameless, because no one is sufficiently interested teo name them. SAFE DRIVING There ought to be a standard course of instructions for new drivers, in which they would be thoroughly drilled in the vital requirements of safe-driving. Ninety-five per cent of all motoring accidents are caused by human delinquency. Careful drivers of well-balanced mentality and normal physical endowments seldom figure in motor-car accidents. If the public could be educated to the necessity of perpetual watchfulness against accident the casualities of the streets and the highways would show a gratify ing decrease.

Look at him as he stands innocently before an editor's desk and pleads in mournful tones for columns of free advertising and publicity. Is he not all that can be' asked of any man? To hear him speak you would believe that he would strike off his right arm in order that you might prosper, that is while he begs upon bended knees for a half page of propaganda. . . Glance at the same man after he has gained his conquest, and gloated over the publicity. His chest swells until the buttons -on his shirts can no longer endure the strain, and release their former threaded positions. Nine out of ten, he will not even stop' when he meets the editor to thank him. In most instances he feels as thought the newspaper has done a noble deed in accomo dating him. His purpose accomplished, and having received his free publi city from the local newspaper, he decides he is in need of adver tising. Does he go to the same newspaper? -No; their rates are too high. Why, that is a robbery to spend $10 for an advertise ment that goes into 5,000 homes. Instead he secure 500 printed, àincy-colored letters, from a small mail order house, costing him $3.00, and buys a number of stamped envelopes from Uncle Sam, and fools himself that he has saved a couple of screaming eagles. He has economized on that amount, but if he would have only spent two additional dollars he would have reached ten times that number. That's economy for those who never stop to think. We are called robbers,, while Uncle Sam and mail order houses are gentlemen. The same man prices your work, writes 12 letters, spending 24 cents for postages, and losing four hours time to obtain prices elsewhere on a commercial printing order of $5.00. If he gets a price of $4.50, he then sends his money to Chi cago or some other city to help pave that place's streets, build their schools, and afford their population with modern conven iences. Some more wise economy, after he pays 29 cents postage, and finds an error in his work, which, if committed by the local printer, would be refused. Yet,newspapers are robbers. Incidentally, it might be stated that he has found the secret of happiness. Following up his philosophy he will exper ience contentment, which is sought by. so .many and found by so few. - - - It certainly is a fact that any man or woman should like a town -that makes it pisible for him òr her to make a ?ivug. Making a living is what most of us are interested in at this time, -and when our town gives this opportunity we should be grateful and like the town. There may be things about the community we would like to see different. That is true of any community where one goes. Venerdì prossimo ricorre lo anniversario del l'adozione e della firma di quello storico documen to che fu chiamato "Proclamazione d'Indipen denza degli Stati Uniti". Fu firmato da uomini coraggiosi e pronti a tutto per liberare l'America dal servaggio inglese. E l'America si liberò di questo servaggio e si avviò lentamente, poi rapi damente per l'influsso degli emigranti, a conqui stare il posto che oggi occupa nel mondo. Noi non vogliamo ricordare proprio di questi giorni che l'America deve principalmente la sua grandezza agli immigrati: vogliamo ricordare soltanto che l'America divenne una Nazione libera e potente, perchè si costituì adottando il principio di uguaglianza di diritti per tutti. E questo .principio oggi più che mai non dovrebbe essere dimenticato da coloro a cui sono affidate le sorti e ilsfuturo di questa grande Repubblica. La data del 4 Luglio è doppiamente cara a tutti gl'Italiani. Essa non segna soltanto l'alba dell'Indipendenza Americana, ma segna anche la nascita di un uomo che divenne un eroe leggen dario della leggenda a cui egli credeva: La libertà di tutti i popoli. Quest'uomo fu Giuseppe Gari baldi. Il 4 Luglio è dunque una data veramente fati dica. Celebriamola da americani e da italiani, e che la duplice celebrazione possa segnare una più intima comunione tra l'Italia e l'America, tra la libertà e l'uguaglianza dei diritti dei due più gran di popoli del mondo. L'Anno del cantore La celebrazione del secondo millenario virgiliano cade, per curiosa coincidenza, in un perio do della storia mondiale che so miglia molto da vicino a quello in cui visse l'immortale poeta latino, un periodo di passaggio da vecchi ideali di dominio a nuovi ideali di pace. Un secolo di guerre interne ed estere aveva preceduto il regno di Augusto. Il mondo antico era stanco di conflitti armati e spar gimento di sangue, come lo è il mondo di oggi. E come fanno adesso, i poeti, gli oratori ed i filosofi d'allora speravano e pre fetizzayano un nuovo millennio. Virgilio, nei suoi giorni, vive va solitaVio attonando la sua lira ai canti della tranquillità pastorale ed ai nuovi ideali popo lari, dissociati dalle guerre e dal le conquiste. E non è strano che la sua influenza sia sopravvis suta ai secoli, nè che egli ci ap parisca investito di potere pro fetico. WISDOM By Dr. Joseph Pantaleone Of what value is a man's knowledge if he doesn't know how to use it to the best possible advantage? Of what use is a man's knowledge if his philosophy of life renders his existence a wretched one? Why should I have any more respect for a man who has stuffed his head full of facts and who shows no other sign of intelligence than that of being a pure memory machine; I say, why should I have any more respect for him than I have for an ordinary five-dollar book?. The chances are that the book will have the material far better organized than he can ever hope to have himself. When shall we stop worshiping brute memory and putting premium on it in our educational system, . when what really counts in life is not the number of facts we have succeeded in storing into our cranium, but rather the way we use our know ledge and the amount of sound philosophy, initiative, originality, courage and idealism we put in our ordinary dealings? The successful man is not necessarily the one who knows most, but he it? the one who thinks most and has the ability and the courage to transform his convictions into action. The writers of all ages have delighted in contrasting knowledge with wisdom and wisdom is always favored above knowledge. But while knowledge is easy to acquire, since any fool can with a little perseverance learn like a parrot countless facts, wisdom on thje other hand, is difficult art to learn and it is not given to every one to be so gifted. Wisdom involves a deep intuitive knowledge it is the supreme art of knowing how to get the most out of life. To have wisdom means to have infinite tact and resourcefulness, to be keenly aware of our numberless relations to all the rest of the world and to have the ability to use these to our best advan tage. What becomes of mere memory when compared to this stupendous art? Imparting wisdom ought to be the primary object of true education, not the development of memory alone. It is wisdom to love all truth, beauty, and goodness for their own sake but how far have we succeeded in imparting this in our schools, college and universities- ' A certain amount of wisdom can be taught in the schools and I believe it can be developed by every man by systematic thinking on life's problems and this is certainly .infinitely more valuable -than the possession of vast stores of encyclopaedic knowledge. INDEPENDENCE DAY There is no day in the year that is. more pre-eminently American than Independence Day, and there is no anniversary dealing with the country that has more significance than the Foutrh of July. It is observed in every state in the Union, and is not only confined to America, but wherever you see citizens of the United States on the Fourth of July you will get a buzz of American enthusiasm. : We can find no preMc sentiments in deahngSvith:4this dayj than the wards uttered by Daniel Webster in his address of July 4, 1851, at the lying of the cornerstone of the new wing of the capitol at Washington, when he said: "On the fourth of July, 1776, the representatives of the United States of America, in Congress assembled, declared that these Colonies are, and ought to be, free and independent states. This declaration, made by most patriotic and resolute men, trusting in the justice of their cause and the protection of Heaven, and yet not without deep solicitude and anxiety, has now stood for seventy-five years. It was sealed in blood. It has met dangers and overcome them. It has had. detractions, and abashed them all. It has has enemies, and conquered them. It has had doubting friends, but it has cleared all doubts away; and now, today, raising its august form higher than the clouds, twenty millions of people contemplate it with hallowed love, and the world beholds it, and the consequences that have followed from it, with profound admiration. "This anniversary animates and gladdens all American hearts. On the other days of the year we may be party men, indulging in controversies more or less important to the public good. - We may have likes and dislikes, and we may maintain our political differ ences, often with warm and sometimes with angry feelings. But today we are all Americans all; and all nothing but Americans. "As the great luminary over our heads," dissapating fogs and mist, now cheers the whole atmosphere, so do the associations connected with this day disperse all sullen -and cloudy weather in the minds and feelings of true Americans. Every man's heart sweels within him. Every man's port and bearing become some what more proud and lofty as he remembers that seventy-five years have rolled away, and that the great inheritance of Liberty is still his, his, undiminished and unimpaired; his, in all its original glory; his to enjoy; his to protect; his to transmit to future generations." A HISTORICAL NOTE ABOUT INDEPENDENCE DAY There is an interesting story connected with the incident of John Hancock's signing of the Declaration of Independence, which explains the frequent reference to one's signature as one's "John Hancock". x . What the colonists were doing, of course, was starting a revolution, and some of the brethren were fearful, lest things might not work out so well. So the cautious ones suggested that perhaps it might better to sign fictitious names or at least sign illegibly so that, in case the document were seized, it would provide no directory of the plotter. Apparently this disgusted Mr. Hancock, who stepped up and boldly taking the pen, or quill, inscribed his name in unusually large and legible letters, at the same time making remarks to the effect that he didn't care if King George himself saw his name there. His action is reported to have quelled all talk of pussy footing. We could hardly hold this sacred national document in the reverence which we now do, if we knew that the signatures were cowardly. And we are indebted, in all probability, to the fearless ness and straightforwardness of the statesmen for the fact that the Declaration of Independence is genuine signature and all. UNEMPLOYMENT AND PATRONIZING HOME FOLKS We have heard much in recent months about boosting our home merchants and not patronizing the chain stores. This is logical doctrine and we believe in patronizing our home merchants and home folks. However lets apply the same thing in another case. You want us to spend our home money with home merchants, yet, if you have a job to let, you go beyond the bounds of our towns to find the labor and right in your own home town there are hundreds of home laborers that are well qualified to do the work. If you have a school to build, a church to erect, a house to paint, or need a bookeeper or clerk for your store, you go to the other place to secure the help you want and ignore home talent. The only difference in this, is that the money people spend in our chain stores perhaps goes directly to Wall Street or ome other distant town, while the wages you pay to outside labor goes into other districts Saturday noon and is perhaps spent in a chain store that night or given to a merchant in some other town that has no interest whatever in your town.

C'è ancora da combattere da soffrire, da vincere. CARDUCCI. MUSSOLINI Un magnifico profilo del Duce tolto dal "New York Journal". Molti di noi essere umani viviamo pigra mente. Lottiamo per piccoli risultati, lavoriamo duramente di regola, o rimaniamo in ozio, che è ancora più duro. Non possiamo fare a meno di sentire che ammontiamo a ben poco, mentre il mondo gira attorno a noi e gli anni ci trascinane frettolosamente verso la tomba. Ma molto diffe rente è la vita che conduce Mussolini. Pensate ad un uomo che pochi anni fa era in carcere come radicale, ora governante dell'Italia, e non tollerante alcun radicalismo. Pensate a Mussolini, che soltanto pochi anni fa era un semplice soldato dell'Esercito Italiano, ferito, perseguitato, esecutore di ordini durante le lunghe marce: ora capo di una Nazione, la cui potenza aumenta sotto la sua guida, milioni di uo mini lo adorano, o lo temono e lo riveriscono. 'A Mussolini poco importa Tuna cosa o l'altra. Voi lo vedete eretto sulla moltitudine nella grande piazza di Firenze, antiche statue nel centro; indie tro una statua equestre di un antico dittatore. THE VALUE OF PRAISE By Dr. Joseph Pantaleone How few are the people who are willing to praise others sincerely for any worth while achievement or for any work or act well done! Too many ofois, through malice, ignorance, or envy, are prone to depreciate or "knock the other fellow rather than to entourage him and give him due credit for his good qualities. We are apt for the same reasons to look more at a man's bad side and to magnify his shortcomings and defects rather than to admire and praise his virtues and to forgive him his imperfections. If we all were more generous in our praise and recognition of a man's better qualities, this world would be a thousand times more pro gressive and interesting. Praise is a great stimulant to achieve ment and without it, the road to worth while things is made more bitter and difficult than it actually is. We are certainly to blame when we ridicule anyone who tries to do something different, which may turn out to be of great value to humanity. Praise, instead of censorship, would be essen tial in all such cases. But how are we going to know whether the man is simply mad or whether he is really a pioneer? We cannot know, so that under the circumstances, "the best thing we can possibly do is to be tolerant with these individuals and to praise them and encourage them whenever they do not become too dangerous. For, it is only out of those men who have the courage to embark on new, solitary and difficult undertaking that will come the gréat leaders of the race. Why then should we make it hard for them to accomplish their work by depreciating them and Idiculing them? The high value of praise in ali.óuch cases will, -hei ef ore, be self-evident. . - But praise has also other great advantages. A little flattery ell used in deserving cases, for instance, will go a long way toward istablishing many solid friendships for us. We all like to be told pleasant things about ourselves. Why should we withold our raise, especially, when a man merits it? If a man has done some- . jing worth while, be the first one to congratulate him and he vviil always reserve a special place for you in his heart. He will ilways remember you above all others for, sadly enough, there re few sincere praisers among us. It cost so little to felicitate people on their achievements, and it yields so much to us both practically and spiritually, that it is only an extremely narrow minded man who will deny his most heartfelt praise to all those ho really deserve it. It is our magnificent privilege and joy to raise all our brothers for whatever success they may achieve in heir constant struggles for the higher and better things of life. Let us all be sincere praisers it pays! REPORTER AND WHAT ELSE? The habits of "Jake" Lingle, Tribune reporter-killed, by an ssassin in Chicago recently, will compel study and comparisons i ordinary newspaper offices where reporters labor and bemoan eir fate. ' Lingle was paid $65 a week for his work but he made weekly ank deposits that might suggest an income from sòme, other ources or a remarkable run of luck at thfe race-tracks. Rumor ays that he helped in the , publication of a racing sheet that provided some of his income. He lived in a luxurious suite in an expensive hotel and he instructed telephone operators that he ust not be disturbed. He appeared late in the mornigto break ast in a hotel, had his chauffeur dirve him tò the office in an xpensive car, visit his newspaper office and spent the remainder f the day, much as he Jbegan it, dining out and perhaps visiting heatres, speakeasies or cabarets, as the notion struck him. What conferences he had during the day is not clear but one ould gather that they were not meetings to promote the welfare ;f the journalistic calling nor to enchance its prestige If Lingle ,vas useful to his newspaper it was in a different manner from ccepted standards. There is plenty of work to be done and overty as frequently stalks there as in any other profession. As alluring almost as the mystery which his death provoked vas his newspaper connection and how he could remain attached o the Tribune payroll for the service he rendered. In newspaper ffices, paAicularly, one mystery is as deep and baffling as the ether. Lingle, it is generally admitted, was on unusually friendly terms with the gang element in Chicago. It is said on good . authority that he was an intimate friend of Al Capone. How, with that background, he could give unbiased service as a reporter is :eyond comprehension. ' If an honest investigation and probe is made into the Lingle lling, it is probable some interesting facts may be brought to ight. . - GOOD SMALL TOWNS NOT LOSING POPULATION The report has gone forth, after straggling Census figures began to appear, that the larger cities are making gains in popu-" lation and that, the smaller towns show losses since thè 1920 census was taken. - But readers will not be deceived into belienving that it reflects on the ability of the smaller towns to hold their own. The fact is that America gains a good many thousand new citizens each year thru immigration, and these all drift into the big eities and remain there. Then, too, our farms are being cut up and more opportunities offered those who want to make a living from he soil and it is the town man who most often grabs at this opportunity, not the city man. He still lives in the community even tho he is not counted in the town's population. It is a fact, however, that in the east, where small towns are loo thick and where they are not progressive, the population is decreasing. This is the result of the universal use of the automobile aid improved highways. Also the tendency of the population move ment westward. The small towns in the west, where they are not thick, but are becoming thicker, is increasing, as the census gures show. The population in these towns especially the new nvns comes from some other source than natural increase; it comes largely from towns farther east. So don't be misled by the census returns. Stop and reason the figures out for yourself. You won't be long in determining, if you are incline to be skeptical, that the small town and rural popula ! 'on stili makes rp the biggest part of the country and will continue in the future, as. in the past to be the real heart of the nation. The progressive small towns, the towns that are not too thick, vili sin vive and grow. NEW CODES OF CRIMINAL LAW IN ITALY The Italian Minister of Justice has presented to Benito Mus solini the text of criminal procedure, together with observations made on the code by Italian magistrates, university professors, :;nd a special commission appointed to examine the code which is collected in four large volumes. Signor Mussolini decided that new codes of criminal law and criminal procedure shall be made public on Oct. 28 next, the eighth r.nniversary of the Fascist revolution, and should enter into force "n the Italian kingdom on July 1 of next year. It is believed that when the new codes enter into force, all exceptional measures passed by the Fascist Government during the last few years, including the institution of the special military tribunal for the defense of the state, will be abolished.

VALUE OF EXPERIENCE By Dr. Joseph Pantaleone Very few people use past experience. Past experience is found largely in books and in the counsel of the wise. A consider able part of the art of wisdom or the art of living is the prudent use of past experience. The counsel of older, the advice of those who -have gone through the mill before is a treasured possession n the eye of the man who reflects. Using our own past experience wisely is an art in itself, but the wisest man is he who consults and uses the experience of the world's greatest thinkers and Jeader thereby widening his views of life and horizon of experience immensely. No one who is bent on getting the most out of life will act impulsively without first consulting past experience. For. example, ast experience tells us that everything worth while in life must be bought by hard work. Therefore, if we waste our spare time, v shall lose our only chance of ever achieving anything capable of giving us" great satisfaction. Past experience has told the world's wisest men that the only road the highest eartly happiness Is that qf love aad service and the road of hard enthusiastic work. Past experience has proved over and over again that honesty is vi. e best business policy and that he who breaks the laws of Na ture, the laws of health and the laws of mind, must pay the price aere on this earth in terms of suffering, wretchedness and misery. Still how many people use this most precious heritage, this extremely valuable past experience? Must we always -be eternally ike children not believing jthat fire, burns until xre touch it, and lever learning the dreadful lessons history te.ici.es? Must we ilways fight each other, hate each other, and separate in acts, in :lans, and nations withouth ever turning our eyes to the priceless science of constructive wisdom which has been bequeathed to us jy the world's great scientists, prophets, reformers, writers and )hnlosephers ? Must a man go on wasting and ìuining his life only :o find out too late that by the intelligent use of past experience :e could have turned his existence from an actual hell to a veri able paradise? This is the fundamental choice-before all of. us .ontinually. Either we decide to use past. experience systematically ?r else we shall drown miserably in the dreadful storm of life. ROSETO. In America vivono alcune delle più grandi Comunità del Mondo. Vi sono a New York più Ebrei che a Gerusalemme; vivono più Irlandesi a Boston che in Cork; vi sono più Polacchi in Chica go che a Varsavia; più Italiani a New York che a Roma. Roseto, nella Contea di Northampton, in Pennsylvania, può vantarsi di essere la sola città in America la cui popolazione è il cento per cento Italiana. E ciò che è più notevole, tutta questa gente o è immigrata da Roseto, un paese dello stesso nome della Provincia di Foggia, o è costi tuita da figli di Rosetani nati in America. .L'intera amministrazione della città è nelle mani di connazionali: il "Chief Burgess", i Consi glieri Comunali, i Giudici di pace, il capo del dipar timento della Polizia ed i suoi subordinati, il Di rettore delie scuele ed i membri del Consiglio Scolastico, l'Assessore delle Tasse, ecc. ecc. Insom ma tutte le autorità cittadine nominate o elette per suffragio popolare sono italiane. Roseto, naturalmente, ha anche il suo setti manale italiano: "La Stella di Roseto", un giorna le ben fatto, diretto con amore da un Rosetano di forza: l'ottimo collega Caporaso. Il linguaggio della strada è italiano; nei Tri bunali non v'è bisogno d'interpetri, perchè i Giu dici, querelanti, imputati, testimoni sono tutti ita liani e vi è usata esclusivamente la nostra lingua. It takes a constantly alert mind to play the game at its best. Let us analyze a little this exceedingly valuable quality which for want of a better word I have called alertness. The alert man avoids those temptations and momentary pleasures which may extort a great price in the future. and involve very much suffering. He is truly a master of the art of weighing pleasures. The alert man is determined to get a firm grip on him self and make himself do things he may not like for the sake of the great future advantages he may derive from these moment ary sacrifices. So alertness means self-mastery. It involves effort, work, watchfulness but in the end it repays itself a thousand fold in the joys and satisfactions it yields. Most men of real wisdom throughout the ages have been advocates of strenuous life for only in hard work are to be found the most complete satisfactions and deepest human joys, and part of the program of the strenuous life is the policy of. constant alertness, keen awareness of all that is going on around us in the world and all that has gone' on in the past as well as the will and understanding to derive the best advantages from the circum stances of lifé as they face us at the present moment. Alertness means being fully conscious of life's great truths and life's mysterious and miraculous nature. Our lives are too short and if we are to make the most magnificent masterpieces possible out of them we cannot afford, to sleepon the job one minute our task is too great we must be ever on the go, ever planning ana looking forward with wise forèsight and ever carrying on our present tasks in the most efficient manner possible. The more we have of alertness the more we develop the God within us the less alert we are, the less God-like and closer to the animal we are for then to live is merely to vegetate. The alert man keeps up to date is as tactful as possible" in all his reaction with his fellows, uses his time wisely exhibits real judgment and does the right thing at the right time. Sometimes however, to be alert may mean to go against- the crowd for the discerning man sees far ahead of his fellows and sees possibilities in new ideas which it takes ages for the rest of the world to'catch up to. So, frequently he stands alone and has thecourage to voice his opinions against the whole world of " such stuff are the world's greatest heroes made and there are many other qualities which the truly alert man must possess. But suffice it to remember that in an age like ours when competition in all fields is so sharp a mental state of constant watchfuSiess and keen alertness is absolutely essential if we are to keep ahead of th other fellow in all our activities. A PLEA AGAINST WAR It took a good many hundred years to bring humanity from the cave man age to a state where he realized that the other fellow had some rights. At one time brute force was the only law, whether it was between two individuals or between two nations. Gradually our minds began to grasp' the idea that might was not always right and we passed laws compelling settlements in courts ' arid punishing the man who resorted to brute force. This, however, applied only to individuals. Our minds had not been educated to a point where we could apply it to nations. -Today there is a strong tendency to outlaw fighting amoung nations the same as we outlawed it amoung individuals. The principle is the same, except that it is ori a larger scale. ' Nationally we are an educated, law-abiding people. Intern ationally we are still in the cave man age. , The average person believes the Bible, tho he may not always follow its teachings. Well, if you believe the Bible you believe in a millenium, because the Bible says there is to be a thousand yeras of peace. Then is it not reasonable that all this talk about werld peace is the beginning of the move, to bring about the millenium? The fighting instinct is still in man, and the only reason the physically strong do not dominate the wear is the fear of the law. There never was a war started that could not have been stopped if all the disinterested nations of the world had notified the war ring nations that war would not be tolerated. Lets start the millenium. , DAYS OF FRIED CHICKEN Many people living in every community remembers the good old days when fried chicken always marked the advent of the circuit rider. These were the days when Methodist conferences in smaller cities" vacated the coops. The good old days when fried chicken greeted the company, and the children wondered whether they would get the drum-stick or the-neck. ; v These were the days vhen fryers sold from $1.25 to $2 per dozen, and the cook got a dollar a week and rations the days when the old man-worked for $40 a month, and his promising son clerked in a store "just to learn a business", and never saw a pay envelope. Old timers rejoice to recall the days of fried chicken and pumpkin pies of the spring wagon and the old gray mare of the church strawberry festival, and kerosene lamps f the Wednesday night prayer meeting and the small wood stove. But not a mother's son of 'em would have these "good old days" back. But it does make a fellow lonesome to talk about the fried chicken, which "Aunt Malinda" used to cook. BATHING BEACH MENACES A girl stood on the edge of a Chicago bathing pool, gay in a bright new bathing suit. Beside her appeared a young man. 'Til get your suit wet for you", he said gaily and he shoved her into the water. This was all right except for two things. The pool at that point was eight feet deep, and the girl did not know how to swim. . The practical jocker dived in after her, but his efforts to save her failed. She drowned, and he himself was rescued only with difficulty. All of which is just an object lesson for the assorted smart a leeks who infest the nation's bathing beaches in .the summer months. It points to a very impressive moral; a bathing beach is. no place for practical jokes, and the worst practical joks imagin able is pushing someone into the water. Lets hope some of our brainless bathing beach nuisances can take the lesson to heart. COLLARS One of the first things a man does when he settles down to his paper in the evening it to take off his collar and hang it on the back of his chair. Then for the first time in the day- he is free from the bond of uniformity. For all the articles of male dress, except shoe laces, the collar is one in which no man can exercise his individuality. His neck may be thick or lean, long or short, wrinkled or smooth, but once inside a collar his neck is no longer his neck; it is simply neck. And as neck, man is always conscious of it, conscious of that constant, irritating pressure of firm linen, that stricture to the flow of eloquence, that torture to the windpipe and vocal cords. So when a man goes home to his wife, he takes his collar off.

Nel secondo anno di vita, cioè al SI Dicembre 1916, il Seg. di Finanza Aurelio Manzi dava il seguente resoconto annuale : Fondo Generale $2057. Socii 457. Nel terzo anno, cioè il 1917, si raggiunse il numero di 500 soci con un fondo di cassa di $3000,00 e siccome la guerra infieriva sempre di più, ad iniziativa della Diritti e Doveri fu organizzato un Comitato misto delle 4 Logge con lo scopo di venire in aiuto delle famiglie dei richiamati, del terremoto d'Abruzzo e della Cro ce Rossa, alla quale furono invia te non poche somme. Con l'entrata in guerra degli Stati Uniti molti soci furono chiamati sotto le armi e con la mancanza di lavoro del dopo guerra, che costrinse molti a la sciare Bridgeport, vi fu un pe riodo di decadenza e si perdet tero più di 200 socci. Quelli che allora reggevano le sorti della Loggia, però, mantennero sem pre lo spirito e il morale di essa molto alto, mentre il Comitato misto intensificava sempre più il suo lavoro dando recite, promuo vendo sottoscrizioni per aiutare gli orfani di guerra. In ogni festa si ricorda dei figli dei fratelli morti. Fu nel 1919, cioè cinque anni dopo la sua fondazione, che la Loggia, incoraggiata da "grup po attivo", decideva di avere una casa propria. Compito arduo, ma che non recava spavento. In fatti incorporati sotto le leggi dello Sato si fondò la Diritti e Doveri Building Corporation che in brevissimo tempo raccolse la bella somma di $4000 che uniti ad altri $100, prelevati dal fondo cassa, fu comprata l'attuale pro prietà al no. 474 East Washing ton Avenue. Anche per questa impijesa si perdettero molti soci, per la ra gione eh un esiguo gruppo di dissidenti, d'incontentabili, a solo spirito di contrarietà, ostacolò, con ogni mezzo- la vendita delle azioni. Ma il "gruppo attivo" fu irremovibile e dopo tanti sacri fici e lavoro, si riusci ad aumen tare il -mensile a $1.25, col van taggio che la Loggia, in meno di quattro anni, non solo comprò altri $3000 di azioni, ma ebbe agio di liquidare quasi tutti gli azionisti fino a diventare la pa drona della magnifica proprietà. Con la compra della casa fu istituito il Club Figli d'Italia, che in breve tempo divenne il ritrovo ufficiale, non solo dei fratelli del la Looggia Diritti e Doveri ma di tutta Ja parte migliore della Co lonia. GARDENS OF ITALY x ' By Mary McKeefe How many of the people who yearly flock to her shores know that Italy is the land of beautiful gardens? Her people are innately lovers of the beautiful and, adapting the natural loveliness of their land, they have made it one of the most picturesque in the world. From the stateliest vistas of the Villa d'Este, on the outskirts xf Tivoli, to the loweliest hovel we find gardens, surpassed by none. Because to those who know and love Italy's gardens, the Villa d'Este, which has recently been restored by the Government, is most familiar, let us journey there first. Leaving Rome over the highway by which, it is said, Hadrian was wont to travel we pass his country estate. . . Winding through the narrow streets at Tivoli we reach the villa. Here, after descending through the crumbling ruins of the house itself, we stand on the highest terrace of the garden. Before us a wide stairway leads to the formal gardens below. Down ita balustrades are cascade miniature waterfalls and buiet pools at the bottom. About are fountains of every description. As her ancient ruins are synonymous with Rome so fountains are synonymous with Italian gardens. They buble forth every where, from under a rocky crevice, from the center of a deep pool. They have been usd in a unique manner in this garden where rock formations have been moulded to resemble " Rome. Laid out in exquisite detail, we identify the Forum, the Coliseum, the Seven Hills, and from these heights we look out toward the Sabine hills, across the valley where Cicero, in his later years, had his farm. At first landing of the stairway is an endless vista of fount ains. They throw their silvery sprays to the heavens through arches of ageles cypress trees. The path beside them leads to a giant waterfall, thundering down from a heisrht of some 100 feet and veiling a cloistered walk beneath in a cloud ofjnist. The cloister leads to an organ loft directly behind the cascade where an organ played by the wind and the water sings a veritable song of nature. As the gardens of d'Este are noted for their fountains so the gardens of the Villa Gueste at Verona are renowned for their ivygrown Cypréjss trees. Laid out on the side of a sheer cliff, this garden rambles over the aged roots gaining a foothold where it would . seem impossible. It is beyond the memory of many men when these hoary trees were young. Their trunks are gnarled and bent as they cling to the side of the cliff but their beauty is a timeless beauty and the scars of centuries are mercifully hidden beneath a blanker of luxuriant iyy. Here too, are fountains, but the are picturesque in a quaint rather than a splendid way. We come upon the spring form the side of a hill or hidden beneath the giant roots of the trees. . At Villa Serbelloni, high above Bellagio, on Lake Como,' there are old" palm ' tréétó. "Situated on a promontory which commands a view on three sides of the lake, its vistas of sky and water linger long in memory. Italy is indeed a land of gardens. If one tires of contemplating her splendid monuments of the past, her astounding progress toward the future, they are on every hand to rest the eye and comfort the spirit. The index number of prices has fallen from 48 per cent above pre-war levels in January last to 34 per cent last week, while wage costs are from 100 to 110 per cent higher. Bateman, of the First Presbyterian Church, Columbus, Miss.; at the annual convention of the Mississippi Press Association, held in that city: "Eternal God, our Heavenly Father, we ask thy blessing upon these newspaper people who are wont to communicate with the ends of the earth. They are people who can smell a revolution in China, people who have a license to enter the gates of prices and potentates, but who will have a mighty hard time getting inside the gates of Paradise. "Have mercy on these people who are-tempted by every devil, from the printer's devil to the devils of newspaper headlines, and these same who are so busy listening to , the sounds of the wires and the songs of the women that offtimes.the voice of God finds no listener among them and no place in their hearts. "Have mercy, O Lord, upon the people who are chased by the Colonial Dames, W. C. T. U., Kiwanis, and Chamber of Commerce. Have mercy on these people who have to hobnob alike with Jew and Gentile, white and black, Democrat and Republican, Baptist, Methodist, Presbyterian and Episcopalian, those who came over on the Mayflower, those who came over in the Cauliflower. "Have mercy, O Lord, on these people and help them in their clash from ballroom to church and back to run-runners, and who have to associate with anybody from Andy Mellon to Andy Gump. Any of them would walk two miles for a good story. "Make this a good convention in the Friendly City. It's an easy matter to break into the Commercial Dispatch. But how will some of them break into the Pearly Gates? We pray Thy blessings upon them. When they have done with newspapers here and stories and their cares are finished here, may they have a finer story for St. Peter than they ever had in newspapers here. And though it is so hard for newspaper men to get into the Kingdom, may they receive a warmer welcome in Jerusalem than they do in Columbus today. Amen." Milioni di giovanetti, ogni anno, sono istruiti nelle pubbliche scuole, dalle minuscole rurali alle gigantesche delle grandi città. Da esse è uscita la maggioranza di coloro che hanno portato al presente progresso la società umana. Da esse usciranno gli uomini futuri, che continueranno questa magnifica opera di civiltà. . Ogni buon cittadino deve interessarsi delle scuole pubbliche, essere di esse orgoglioso, e or goglioso maggiormente di far parte di una Nazio ne che garantisce l'istruzione a ogni fanciullo. Il sistema delle scuole pubbliche americane è il più grande del mondo, perchè a base assoluta mente democratica, perchè universale. Ed è il migliore perchè le nostre scuole sono aperte a tutti: ricchi e poveri, anzi sono obbliga torie nel senso più alto della parola. Amalo come ameresti un tuo fratello; amalo quando ti accarezza e quando ti rimprove ra, quando giuste e quando ti par che sia ingiu sto; amalo quando è allegro e affabile ? e amalo anche di più quando lo vedi triste. Instead of the expected or maybe not expected thick meat sandwiches, fruit, eggs and coffee, the searcher found the skins of the potatoes which the man's children had eaten for supper the night before. He had gone without food quite cheerfully until his strength gave away. He hadn't wanted to ask for aid. He had too much pride, If a man had a family -it was his duty to support the family, he reasoned. The other employes in this man's department immediately took up a collection und bought food for him and his family. Yon can't o-pf lw always with extreme selfishness. BUSINESS ON THE UPGRADE By Powell Crosley, Jr. It has been said that good or Dad business is largely the result of a state of mind. When every ne believes that business is good, people buy freely and prices go up. All along the line there is buying in anticipation of requirements, and price advances, rather than actual needs. The United States has unexcelled production facilities and our factories keep pace with the growth of business -optimism, instead of being governed by the fundamental law of supply and demand. When business is good we all think it is a lot better than really is the case, and when it is bad, we likewise think it is much worse than is really true. When something happens to change the state of mind of people, conservation and pessimism rule. The public thinks hard times exist and buys only when there is the direst need for mer chandise. Production drops and prices are reduced in an effort to stimulate business that does not exist. As the world's greatest individual market, this country soon absorbs surplus stocks when there is a sharp decline in production, .such as occurred last winter and spring. Every sign points to the fact that business in the United States has met the turn in the l.oad and is on upgrade. There should be rapid improcement, and I, for one, feel most optimistic about the future and anticipate a more rapid come-back than might be hoped for had the depression of the past few months come more gradually instead of abruptly, as was the case. 1 NOSTRI FIGLI. Le nostre più rosee speranze sono basate sul futuro dei nostri figli. Anche quando la natura ci è stata madrigna, come la fortuna, speriamo sem pre che esse siano buone madri pei nostri figli. E facciamo del nostro meglio per spianar loro il cammino e per indirizzarli sulla via che mena al successo. La via migliore è quella che si fonda sull'edu cazione. Ed in questo paese è facile seguirla. Tut to quello che occorre è la buona volontà di appren dere e di mettere in pratica quello che si apprende. Il nuovo anno scolastico è ora cominciato e con esso il lavoro utile dei nòstri figli. Esso non porta frutti immediati, ma prepara raccolto ab bondante e sicuro. Tutto quello che occorre è la buona volontà e la persistenza degli scolari ed il continuato spirito di sacrificio dei genitori. Il mantenere figli a scuola, costa danaro e sacri . f ici. Ma quello che si spende non è mai perduto. Molti dei nostri la grande maggioranza forse hanno ricevuto una coltura superficiale. Parte di essi non ne ha avuto affatto.. Essi com prendono la necessità di saper leggere e scrivere, ma non quella di apprendere le molte cose che il progresso e la scienza hanno adagiato sul nostro cammino. Chi non ha studiato mai non può com prendere il godimento che l'apprendere cose nuo ve ed utili concede allo studente volenteroso. E non comprendendole, non può concepire al suo giusto valore la necessità di secondare la volontà allo studio dei propri figli. Chi va a scuola lavora mentalmente. E molti fra i nostri connazionali, che non hanno avuto -l'opportunità di apprendere per conto proprio, non concepiscono l'importanza e la necessità di dare allo studente anche delle ore di riposo e di svago. L'anno scolastico è lungo. Ma la onesta cooperazione dei genitori potrà accorciarlo o ren derlo meno pesante. Lo studente ha bisgno di svolgere la sua attività in un ambiente sereno. E . questo ambiente sereno non può essere che la casa ove nacque e dove si svolgono tutte le sue attività. Se un tale ambiente viene concesso allo studente, egli progredisce nella via del bene ed ama lo stu dio, appunto perchè lo studio allarga a poco a poco il suo orizzonte e lo mette in grado di comprendere anche le cose più difficili. La scuola è quella che offre alla mente l'op portunità di migliorare e di evolversi. Ed il pro gresso è continuo qùando l'educazione viene im partita e si svolge nel modo indicato dall'esperien za e delle condizioni in cui la vita si svolge. I geni tori dovrebbero essere i primi a secondare lo sfor zo incessante ed onesto dei loro figli ed arricchire la loro mente di nuove condizioni utili. Quando mancano a questo dovere il progresso dei figli procede in modo lento ed incerto. E la colpa non è certo dello studente. I nostri figli sono la nostra vita e la nostra speranza. Secondiamoli nel loro sforzo di conqui ste, con l'avvenire, la stima ed il rispetto dei loro simili. - LA CONVENZIONE DEI FIGLI D'ITALIA DEL CONNECTICUT. La loro depressione, dicono gli osservatori, è di carattere psicilogico. Il vasto ambiente lamentoso in cui vivono li dispone .irresistibil mente alla lamentela. Il che può esser vero. Le prime avvertono il disagio dell azienda che le impiega ed in buona parte debbono aecon tentarsi di compensi minori, ciò che è un disastro, perchè ag grava e prolunga sulle loro spal le la schiavitù delle ipoteche impostesi con le compre a paga menti rateali. Esse non hanno scusa per rimandare gli agenti esattori, perchè non sono disoccupate, e spessissimo il salario non basta a soddisfare gli obblighi contratti in un più favorevole periodo di tempo. Max Gardner of North Carolina goes the credit for the most, and perhaps the only constructive substitute for the idiocy of tree sitting. Some of our business men have just discovered that truth. And they are all hot and bothered about it. For years "the stock ings hung by the fireside" have been filled with satisfying re gularity and liberality. People came in constantly and bought without argument. Everybody was having a wonderful time. But something has happened. And the bewildered ones are asking each other, "Where has business gone?" Well, where HAS business gone? The plain truth is that business hasn't gone anywhere. It is right here in our city. Always has been, always will be. But business nowadays is operating on the "cafeteria" plan. HARD TIMES IN AMERICA We are having hard times ; the streets are full of automobiles, going, as Will Rogers says, nowhere in particular but in a great hurry to get there; times are so hard that is is difficult to find parking places for our automobiles ; we have in the United States about twentyfive million automobiles, or only about one for every five of us; if time were not so hard, we would no doubt all have an automobile. We are right up against it; we sawr a girl last week so hard up she did not have silk stockings, and rather than wear rayon she wore none at all; of the thousands of girls, it is almost unbe lievable that one should have to do without silk stockings, but that is not at all the consumption of cigarettes increased only about 5,000,000 packages last year, whereas everybody knows it should have increased by twice that amount. Times are sure hard we were able to obtain a seat at the movie after waiting only 20 minutes, when by rights we should have had to wait at least an hour; the drug store got along by installing only two extra fountains this summer, which shows how bad things really are, but an extra show case for lipsticks, two extra racks for magazines and a lunch counter cut into the druggist's earnings and made him realize how hard times are. And to make things worse, every vacant, lot in America has a miniature golf course on it and it looks like times are getting" so hard that they're going to have to start tearing town perfect ly good buildings to make room for more "peewee" golf courses. And if a fellow wants to play on one of the pesky things he has to wait nearly an hour before he can get to start and then gets run over, knocked down and hit by golf balls before he finishes. Every one of the miniature courses is crowded day and night. Yes, times are hard. When will times be better? It is almost impossible to find a parking space near a movie theatre, miniature golf or other place of amusent a terrible condition. Something really ought to be done to require the hot-dog stands to carry on hand a sufficient s upply of food to feed the crowds ; and this way of building grand stands, movie theatres, stadiums and other places of amusement only half large enough to seat those attending ought to be handled vigorously. Yes, the times are hard ; the grits or bacon; it takes all of his time to sell canned peaches, canned salmon, canned soup, canned meats and even canned apple sauce; the dry goods merchant gingham, muslin and denim remain on his shelves, while his clerks waste all their time selling such things as silk and rayon; the hardware store has no demand for plows, wire fencing and nails, but he cannot supply the demand for radios, electric perco lators, vacuum cleaners et cetera; yes, the times are hard. MAKE YOUR PURCHASES NOW Within the last few months prices have taken a terrific fall due to the depression, and the buying public, if it is in a position to make purchases, should do so now. As we .scan the market, pages of various newspapers we are agreeable surprised witfi the downward trend. Practically very commodity can be bought much cheaper than at any time since the war, and we would suggest that it is profitable to buy right now. When business gets back to normal there will be an upward trend of these prices so that it is the part of good business to buy now. THE MOUNTING TOLL OF TAXATION One sixth of this contry's total earning capacity, is our toll lo taxation, according to Merle Thorpe in Nation's Business. Our tax bill, he says, is nearly 13 billion dollars yearly, "while the yearly earnings of all of us men, women and children is 80 billion. Mr. Thorpe likewise points out that one person out of every eleven who are gainfully employed, is a public employee, while not so many years ago it required only one out of every 22 persons to perform the services we demanded of Government. Much of this taxation bill is due to the more or less general theory that anything furnishad by the Government is free. Therefore business men continue to boost for more Governmental activities, only to find that the old economic law holds good, and eventually we pay for all we get. EDITORS ARE HUMAN When a doubtful situation arises in a town it is quite the fashion to remark that "the paper ought to say something about that." The average citizen feels quite certain he could run a news paper better than the editor does, and if he were publisher -of that sheet he'd show 'em, you bet. As a matter of fact, if he has horse sense he would do just as the editor does, put the soft pedal on family rows, church squabbles, scandals not involving principles, and such matters of minor importance as will adjust themselves with the passing of time. The newspaper critic ought not to expect the newspaper man to advance or attack any proposition which he himself hasn't the courage to support or assail over his own signature. . The editor is willing, even eager, to push any project in the public interest. But he is not willing to pull chestnuts out of the fire for individual or minorities. TO FULL TO MOVE The cry of suffering America would appear to be "Give Us Something New To Sell That Everybody Wants To Buy" and preferably something to play with ! We are burdened not with poverty but a plethora of prosperity. Saturation is the cause. We do not wear enough cotton or leather ; we do not eat enough sugar or wheat. There is not room enough in the roads for any more motor cars and their sale lags in consequence. Congestion is at the bottom of it all. This prevails in every line. There is even too much money to be put in profitable employment. In short, the nation has been playing the greedy boy until it is stuffed too full to move. La biografia di Lincoln, ma gnifico lavoro di un'illustre scrittrice americana, ha man dato in bancarotta la casa editri ce che si organizzò per lanciarla, nell'illusione che avrebbe fatto un successo. La biografia di Jefferson, con quelle monumentali lettere che egli suoleva scrivere agl'inse gnanti dei figli, e che rappre sentano miracoli di profezia, gia ce ignorata in polverosi cantucci di librerie. Ma il libro intitolato "La Strana Morte del Presidente Harding", rivelante capolavori di corruzioni politiche, mostruose passioni, mostruosamente soddi sfatte, di altolocati personaggi, uccisioni raccapriccianti, atti camorristici che farebbero .im pallidire Erricone, ecc. ecc. è andato e seguita andare a ruba. Chi non leggerà questo volu me? Vi si apprenderà come abbia fatto l'illustre protagonista per guadagnare in otto anni trenta milioni di dollari, di cui dieci per duti alle corse dei cavali. Non è sufficiente ciò, per ac cendere la smania di divorarlo al più presto? Non si creda che lo egregio dottore lascerà o sta-per lasciare Brid geport, dove in poco più di sei mesi si è conqui stata una vasta legione di amici, di ammiratori, di conoscenti. Egli solo andrà a New Britain il giorno del "Columbus Day", invi tato da quelle Associa zioni a commemorare Cristoforo Colombo. Il Dr. Filippo Martuc ci che oltre, ad un Escu lapio valente laureato con onore dalla Madre delle Università Italia ne è un letterato insi gne ed un parlatore fecondo. La sua conferènza sul la "Tubercolosi", tenuta una decina d'anni fa e l'altra sulla "Diritti e Doveri", tenuta ultima mente, sono due monu menti di coltura, di intel ligenza, di -sapere, di scienza, di esperienza della vita. Il distinto connaziona le, di cui i lettori della Sentinella sanno l'alto pregio poetico, siamo certi, porterà a New Britain tutta la fiamma ardente della sua anima itlianissima, e gl'Italiani tutti avranno occasione, ascoltandolo, di trascor rere del magnifico godi mento intellettuale. Il Dr. Martucci parle rà a New Britain nel dopopranzo. La sera è Loratore uf iciale alla com memorazione Co lombiana che faranno le quattro Loggie e Socie tà Riunite al Beach Hotel. In tal modo, il quartiere di "Cicero", il "Loon", di Chicago, ( diverranno meta di tante spe i ranze, ispiraeioni di uomini e donne, adulti e piccini, perche il libro, naturalmente, andrà nel le mani di tutti. Poi se ne viene il "New York Times" e si domanda come mai la generazione crescente ignora chi siano Washington e Lincoln. 1 non sappia come si chiami la ca pitale degli Stati Uniti, s'infischi di tutto lo scibile classico e di sprezzi profondamente la fa miglia. PUBLIO VIRGILIO MAROWE Duemila anni fa nasceva a Mantova Publio Virgilio Marone uno dei più grandi Poeti della Latinità. L'Italia opportunamente sta festeggiando da più mesi la ricorrenza che in questo mese si è mag giormente intensificata. Bridgeport, che ha al suo attivo ricordi patrii indimenticabili, commemorerà il Cantore di Roma con una festa abbinata a quella di Colombo, che avrà luogo i particolari sono in altra parte di questo giornale all'Hotel Beach. Virgilio, come con limpida frase ha detto il Duce d'Italia, è il primp ed il più alto poeta impe riate, ÌCgli sorge quando Roma, esaurito il ciclo re pubblicano della sua storia, sembra rinascere con Augusto e rinnovarsi nel Dominio mondiale. Il suo verso dona espressione imperitura e diffusione universale agli ideali di Roma nuova col sublime magistero dell'arte. Egli fu il sommo Poeta dei campi. Dopo che nelle "Georgiche" ebbe levato ai numi agresti della sua stirpe un sacro bosco bello, còme non mai l'ebbero i Numi di Grecia, colse i rami plella quercia e dell'alloro e ne intreccio una eorpna, per la fronte di Augusto. Perchè il Poeta veramente grande sa che la sua voce non deve essere mai lusinga né d'orecchie, ne d'animo. Sa che il suo canto dev'essere virtù civilmente opera trice. Sa che col suono della sua cedra Anf ione fece sorgere le mura a difese della sua Tebe- Secondo l'immortale egloga di Virgilio, noi dopo il volo di venti secoli, ci avviciniamo ancora alla soglia di uno dei grandi anni nei quali l'Uma nìt fleve rinnovellare la sua yita. poeta, che sta attraverso secoli e secoli sulle vette àell? Arte, per cui Dante lo volle a suo Maestro e guida nel suo cammino dell'al di là at- j traverso 1 Inferno ed il Purgatorio, rimane come l'eterno faro delle genti, P&strq dei naviganti. Da ' Ogni parte aeU Creano osservano per levarne ì pùnti, e le rotte in -apparenza anche opposte sono guidate dalla-medesima luce. Anche quando caduto l'Impero d'Occidente altri ed altra genti Rombarono dal Nord e dal l'Oriente sul sacro suolo di Romaiche portavano 'altre leggi d'invasione, di conquista, di rapina che occuparono gran parte del Mediterraneo ed eb bero i loro fasti ed i loro poeti, che cantarono le loro glorie e le loro conquiste, man non distrutto ed indistruttibile rimaneva sotto le invasioni il popolo latino come l'"Humus" fecondo sotto le paurose alluvioni. - E corsero secoli e secoli. E di un tratto in un momento in cui sembrava che tutto il móndoi cibile dolesse crollare ih una convulsione immane come non era ancpra yista, ìa voce agi-jsoea, co stituì ìl Faró di -saldezza poh solò "3el suo popolo; mg, iurnijig apche la rotta degli altri popoli, in apparenza opposta, ma dalla stessa luce ulu- imp at a. v-"? . visv' --: Nessuno potrà mai sradicare questo glorioso ceppo latino. Esso rigermogliò sempre nel secoli, anche quando i rami ed il fusto furono stroncati, perchè quando sul quadrante dei secoli battono le ore fatali, parla nel cuore dei popoli il segreto genio delle stirpi e prepara le eroiche difese e le alacri riscosse, in nome della pace: della giu stizia, dell'operosa gioia dei campi, ghg Virgilio cantò nei sijgi crm -immorsali6 "r . Più saggia, dunqlie non poteva essere la dispo siziope $el Governo Patrio, alla quale, se non si è Unito, dovrebbe unirsi tutto il grande pensiero degl'Italiani all'Estero, Sia il sommo, cantore delle "Georgiche", che amò più di tutto la gran Madre Italia, alla quale chiese ristoro dopo l'aspra fatica dello stilo, il nume tutelare della nostra stirpe e l'humus seco lare e sempre nuovo che continui a fecondare i nuovi virgulti della latinità che ora spuntano in tutte le terre del mondo. Salve, o sommo. Lavorare, perchè il lavoro vuol dire alle grezza, coraggio, attività del sangue, pace dello spirito, sicurezza della coscienza, dignità della vita perchè chi lavora prega, spera, combatte, semina costruisce per sè e per gli altri, per il pre sente e per l'avvenire, e spande intorno con l'e sempio il fiore il polline fecondo; e trasfonde nel petto altrui l'onestà, la salute, la forza dell'anima sua..
